reviews.review_text: I'm going to begin this review with a confession: Far Cry 2 is my favorite game in the Far Cry series.  Since that one was so well received, let me go for a second confession: Far Cry 2 is probably the least popular game in the Far Cry series.  It is my favorite game in the series because of the overall 'attitude' of the game. It is everything Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is not. It is the very antithesis of Blood Dragon: Where Blood Dragon revels in being irreverent, ridiculous, and detached from reality, Far Cry 2 is gritty, realistic, and dark. It is a modern retelling of The Heart of Darkness, in which you play a mercenary hunting an arms dealer in a fictional African country, all the while battling malaria.  It is not the most open world. You are not a bullet sponge. Health does not regenerate, and in fact guns will jam on you based on how dirty they are. There isn't even a skill tree or a quick melee button (you have to manually switch to your machete). However, it is probably the single most immersive gave I've played in a long time if not ever, and a fantastic story takes you through a unique setting not often seen (or done well) in games.  Gameplay: Far Cry 2 is dated. It's not unplayable, but if you've recently played some of the other Far Cry games then the absence of some features is certainly conspicuous. However, the guns have punch, the player is fragile, fire is dangerous (it's a dry African setting), and the game reeks of realism. Yes, reeks. The main reasons people hated this game were because your character has malaria and because guns jam. Guns jamming is avoidable but you do have to address the malaria from time to time. It plays like a survival game, because you have to struggle to win (without it being too punishing). There's no skill tree and you have to really work for your equipment upgrades. While this isn't for everyone, if you go in expecting this kind of gameplay, you're going to enjoy the game more than someone going in blind.  8/10   Graphics/Visual Experience: While the game is old, the graphics aren't too bad. I go back and play this every once in a while and I'm blown away by some of the nature scenes. The game is truly impressive when compared to other games released at the time and that gives it some true staying power. The environment is immersive (the first game I ever actually got lost in: The first day I played it, I played it for 12 hours straight) and while it's not in the same way characters in Skyrim have complete lives, it's still capable of sucking you in if you let it. The score that follows accounts for both the game being dated but still capable of impressing me:  7.75/10   Sound: The song from the title screen is still on my phone somewhere. Guns don't always have a bassy sound but always feel like they have some punch. Ambient/background noise is done well, gives the environment some life without having wild animals like 3 and 4 do.  7.5/10   Replayability: Not as much as the later games in the series. The main draw of 2 is the immersion and story. While the environment can suck you in, it's not particularly fun to explore because you don't get the feeling of missing out on interesting things as you drive from place to place. If you're like me you'll want to play and play until you finish the story, but there is a hard ending and that also kills post-story replayability.  5.5/10   How it Runs: It's still a demanding game. I've played games released in late 2015 that made my computer run hot less often than this game. However, there are very rarely spikes in the resources the game needs to play smoothly. Physics aren't too intense, the worst the lag will probably get is when there's a bunch of fire on the screen. This is the first game with fire propagation, which they certainly wanted to show off. They actually had to set a limit because during testing, there were times when the entire in-game world was set on fire without the limit in place.

Far Cry 2 is a open world first person shooter with some small RPG elements set in the African savannah.  You have a aim, killing the Jackal, the person who supply the African war groups with weapons and causes the whole country to suffer even more. When arriving in Africa you get driven by a taxi driver to the main city Pala. While driving through the magnificent looking landscape you see several things and also notice your Malaria. You get a Malaria attack and get unconscious. You wake up in a house in Pala and see your enemy, the jackal. He decides who lifes and dies and he lets you alive. After this you have to get out and get unconscious again after a while. You get saved by a group called UFLL. There are 2 groups who have war against each other. UFLL and APR. Who is the good and the bad have you to decide even though both are not perfect. I personally prefer the UFLL. Only my opinion though. On your way through the story you visit a lot of places and meet your buddies who help you. I wont say more to dont spoiler too much.  The gameplay is actually very nice. I love the first person weapon handling. It feels realistic and there is a big range of weapons to choose from. All being buyable in the Weapon Store for diamonds. Thats the currency of the game. You can also buy upgrades for you and your weapon. Your weapons degrade! Maybe too fast for some but for me its fine, especially with upgrades. You can change them for free in your Weapon room and 'repair' them like that. I wouldnt recommend using weapons of the enemies, they are weak and in bad quality. You often get quests to finish certain aims. The mission variety is fine even though not big. But its fine for my taste. You mostly get diamonds or medicine for completing quests. You can also find collectables in the game. Diamond suitcases with 1-3 diamonds in each and Jackal tapes. There is a incredible amount of this stuff. Also there are 8 gold AKs in the whole world. The difficulty is higher than normal. Dont try rushing over the enemy, this mostly wont work. You always have to watch out. And the health doesnt regenerate, at least not completely. You need some sort of medics to heal yourself and you cant carry unlimited of those. The open world is extremely big and you have your feet, cars, boats or the bus to reach several places. Busses are helpful for those who prefer fast traveling even though the busses just have 5 stations per map. Enough for me though. The fact that you have to travel actually I like about the game. Its nice visiting the landscape and I like this sort of oldschool traveling. Some may dont like this sort of system but I love it. While travelling you will often pass some sort of checkpoints of the enemy who will shoot you on sight. Each of those checkpoints have some special ammo or medicine. Mostly with around 5 enemies at each point. A little bit annoying about this game is the way how the Enemies respawn and hunt you with their cars after they saw you. You mostly have to kill the car until you can continue passing. Also the enemy is often faster than you. After you erased a point, the enemies will respawn fast after going away and come back and that is the most negative point about the game. I got used to it, even though I agree its not perfect. Beside of those checkpoints there are also other places which are often specially named. Places like bases of the enemy. Trainyards, camps, whatever. There are often 10+ enemies and you should watch out, most of those places you see automatically while doing missions. There are also animals in the nature, around 5 sorts of animals in the whole game. Realistic behaviour and they shun humans. I often think they could add more animals and also hunting animals but on the other hand its not as unrealistic as in Far Cry 3. The animals there are to much if you ask me.  The graphics and engine in general are amazing. I rarely saw so much realism. The whole engine simulates real world nature. Wind, rain, sun and day cycle. The graphics in general look amazing. Especially fire effects. Definitely 10/10 in terms of graphics especially for 2008. Some say Crysis or CryEngine 2 is better but I think they are equivalent. The Dunia Engine just has its aim on realistic day/night cylcle and weather cycle. A little part of the CryEngine is in the Dunia Engine btw! The Music is also amazing and fits perfectly into the whole setting. The African setting like that is pretty unique and thats great.  The Multiplayer is ok. Some sort of CoD sort of Multiplayer which is just more realistic in general. Not many people play it online anymore though.  Fortunes Edition DLC: This is a small DLC which adds 3 new weapons, some new cars and some new Multiplayer maps. Nothing special but not bad either.  And now our favorite part. Can it compete against Far Cry 3? I say yes. Its maybe not everyones taste but Far Cry 2 counts to my favorite games and can compete against Far Cry 3. It maybe doesnt have so many gameplay tweaks as Far Cry 3 but I like this rustical way how Far Cry 2 handles everything. Reminds me a little bit of oldschool games. Not a lot of gimmicks but everything thats neccessary to have a nice game. I love the atmosphere of the game. The whole nature is amazing and the music fits perfectly into the game. Maybe its even better than Far Cry 3 in this part.  Some of you are maybe spoilered of Far Cry 3. Try ignoring the things that Far Cry 3 does better. I already played the game 2009 and I loved it back then. Far Cry 2 maybe isnt perfect but it does a lot of things right and it has a great experience. You should definitely try it especially because of the price. I think the game will get 9/10 from me, maybe overrated but I think this score fits good for me. Make yourself an own picture of the game and dont listen to people who say its bad.

Give me FarCry 2 any day. Destroyable gas stations, respawning checkpoints (I have no idea why people hated these with so much passion. Park the truck, pull out a launcher and blow the ♥♥♥♥ up!!), diamond discoveries, different landscapes with unique terrain. FarCry 3 is like the hot supermodel that doesn't have all the intelligence that a normal girlfriend does: She's great to look at but the depth of conversation and the ability to draw you in are severely lacking. I have an extremely difficult time believing that the main character matured from no combat experience to wiping out an entire cartel.  This was my review for FC3 but I feel it also belongs here. I won't play FC4 and probably won't touch Primal either. FC and FC2 were by far and away the best of the series. What other games allow you to burn dry grasslands to draw out your enemies like the cocaine runners did in Crocodile Dundee 2? None. The AI is spot on in all their responses and for a game this old, they take cover really well. Landscape was incredibly well detailed to the point you would think it's a Bethesda title and this game made you WORK for victory. Shame on all you crybabies that ♥♥♥♥♥ed and moaned about Malaria or jamming guns or respawning guardposts. Y'all missed the damn point of the revolutionary gameplay that made you HUNT your enemy. I felt like a lethal predator sneaking around with my silenced handgun, silenced shotty (Anton Sigur, anyone?), and a flamethrower.  I also learned that the only tool you'll need in life to fix engine, radiator and body damage is a ratchet.

After my first review that didn't seem helpful to a lot of people and the fact that I had nothing positive to say about the game, I gave Far Cry 2 a second try.   The graphics are great and the weapons and upgrades are good as well. There is plenty of action, diamonds want to be found and the map is huge.  Unfortunately I still find many things that I don't like and that still annoy me a lot.   First there is the car driving, this gets annoying really quickly as you constantly have to drive from one end of the map to the other and back again. It doesn't help that you cannot truly clear out road blocks, enemies will respawn even though you have cleared the camp. You can just 'scout' these camps, thats all. This way, you will have plenty of shootouts as you often have to step out of your car and kill people before you can head on. Im also missing a fast travel system to locations you have scouted or at least to safehouses. Driving becomes a chore.  Secondly there is this awful map. It is a good idea, but ultimately it is obstructing your sight and is annoying. This minimap is missing several options, you as a player should have control over. Hold the GPS in one hand and a pistol in the other for instance. Or have the map in your left hand be set on the left side of the screen and not right in the middle. Or have a GTAish GPS in your HUD. Instead you can hardly see whats in front of you.   The buddy system is interesting, but ultimately lacks the immersion to bond with your partner(s), they seem expendable and are badly written.  The story is bland: Kill the Jackal. I'm totally missing storyline here, that leads you through the game, tells you an actuall story. Instead the game presents you unrelated quests of killing that repeat themselves. After all you don't even know what you are actually doing and why you are in Africa.  Are you there for a Malaria cure, that you got there to begin with? Are you there to befriend the Jackal? Kill Factions or not? What was the purpose of it all? Bring refugees across the border? I thought Im a mercenary, there to make a profit, well guess I lost my identity.  The AI is pretty annoying as well, granted they try to surround you, but it seems even if you are hiding they always come from behind, spot you through obstacles and shoot you through high grass and plants where you could only make prediction shots.   SPOILERS:  But the worst of all is the miraculous ressurection of your so called buddies. First they will be killed in the bar. Then at the end every buddy is there again in a shootout for some stupid diamonds. Even if you shoot a buddy yourself during the game, but whole clips in them, they will come back.  This makes no sense at all, 'story' or otherwise.
Best far cry ever...all other Far Cry titles are easy childish games where as this one has grit

This is one of the best shooters I've ever played, better than the games afterwards. The open world activities are structured in a very simplistic way, but achieving your objectives is anything but simple. You constantly feel like you're under threat of being attacked when you're outside, and you have to spend about 15 minutes preparing for each mission. Picking and replacing your weapons and maybe even getting new Malaria pills. There's a lot to contend with, you have to take cover and buy yourself time to heal yourself, you need to make sure your weapons don't jam, and you need to defend the buddies you bring with you because they absolutely can die, leaving them gone for the rest of the game. All of this means that pulling off the missions feels INCREDIBLY rewarding.  Honestly I've never played a shooter as immersive as this, and yes the malria and guard post respawn issue is annoying, but not enough to break the game entirely. It's dynamic, it's dark and the world actually feels hostile to you rather than an open world playground. If you're willing to put up with its quirks, you'll find one of the most rewarding shooters of last gen here. They don't make 'em like this anymore.

Pros: +Good variety of very different weapons, and they are all fun to use. +Beautiful graphics +Great deal of freedom when doing missions and freedom to do things when you want to do them. +Gun degradding, wound healing, and no pausing to look at a map add to the immersion. +Always plenty of guys to shoot and generally good AI  Cons:  - GENERALLY good AI. On harder difficulties, they can see through vegetation unusally well, but not consistently. They're also bullet sponges if you don't use explosives, shotguns, and sniper rifles. Sometimes they are smart and try to flank you, other times they bum rush you like it's their first time playing a shooter.  - Voice acting is very odd; it feels rushed. Considering what kind of game this is trying to be though, this isn't a big deal because...  - ... the plot is more of an excuse to be shooting people in Africa than an actual story.  - Driving to objectives is a 'female dog' (thanks for the PG censorship on an M rated game, Valve) and a half with all the patrols and guard posts that respawn if you walk more than 100m away. Constatnly changing up your play style is what makes this game so much fun. It's my go-to game if I just want to relax after a hard day. They fly out sideways about 5-7 feet in a perfectly straight line.  Subjective score: 10/10 - Would bless the rains down in Africa again... but fire spreads more easily when it's dry. This game is one of the best games I have played. This game gets some negative feedback because of its difficulty, but I will explain why you should play it. First off, Far Cry 2 still looks absolutely gorgeous. Africa has never looked better in a game. You will find zebras and gazelles roaming the grasses. You will enjoy mountains, waterfalls, and canyons, travel across the small lakes, visit Pala, Sefapane, and Mosate Selao, and speed across the dirt roads to hunt for enemies.  The gunplay in Far Cry 2 is undoubtedly realistic. This is no Call of Duty; your guns behave like real ones and there is not much 'running and gunning' unless you are playing on easy. There is gun jamming and degradation, so you will need to take care of them. There are weapons for everyone. There are multiple rocket launchers, grenade launchers, pistols, machine pistols, snipers, and explosives. There is even a dart rifle and a explosive crossbow! The missions are fun but may get boring. I would advise playing on Hardcore or Infamous difficulties because when you play on them, the game becomes much more challenging and even more realistic. There are respawning outposts with enemies, and these provide good fun since you never run out of people that are trying to kill you. Many people are not used to such a harsh game; expect everybody outside of the Ceasefire zones to try to kill you. Is that good? Your call. There are tons of weapon upgrades and some vehicle upgrades, plus upgrades that will allow you to carry more ammunition or molotovs. The second half of the world unlocks when you complete half the missions in the game, and this second world adds new Jeeps, boats, and guns, plus new locations to explore. Fire is my favorite part of the game because it is so well-done. The fire is better than Far Cry 3 because it was not designed to play a large role in Far Cry 3. Far Cry 2 has seasons and rain, so expect fire to work less effectively when the grass is green or there is a downpour. When the grass is dry and there is no rain, fire becomes the game changer. If I feel overwhelmed during gameplay, I may throw a molotov cocktail into some dry grass to start a (potentially massive) fire. This fire scatters enemies, forcing them to change their attack plan; if you are lucky, you may even get one to burn to death.  The audio in this game also never ceases to impress me. You can hear birds and monkeys in the trees, the wind rustling the leaves, the whine of the mounted gun as it swivels. When you are around enemies, you will hear their conversations (they sound believable). The music in this game is a nice change as it is what you would expect and African band to play.  You have malaria during the game, and it puts an interesting spin on your gameplay. You may have to wait out a malaria occurence, and this can kill you. The best tactic to do is throw a molotov and hurry to cover. Note that it took me 30 hours to complete my first playthrough. After that, you can do a new one on a harder difficulty (feel free to change difficulty anytime you want). The ending of the game is unexpectedly deep.  All in all, this is a game like no other. Everything I said above amount to an amazing experience. This is an experience like no other that can be had, during a sale, for just $2.50.

And yes, fast travel is incredibly limited, forcing you to drive around through the same checkpoints of infinitely respawning guards over and over again.  Still, I recommend you give it a try. It's one of the most immersive and wildly unpredictable FPSs I've played. And hey, I'll take those infinitely respawning guards over the guards in Far Cry 3 that completely disappear forever once you clear an outpost. At least in this game I can always find somebody to shoot.

What's best about Far Cry 2?The true answer is that there is no one thing that can be considered best about Far Cry 2. Its brilliance lies in the fact that it is more than the sum of its already impressive parts. Essentially the game is a playground that caters for whatever mood players find themselves in. Want to storm into an enemy encampment in broad daylight John Rambo style, perhaps running a few unfortunate soldiers down with a MG-mounted Jeep before letting loose with your grenade launcher? Go ahead. Prefer to fast-forward the incredible day/night cycle to midnight by taking a nap in one of the Safe Houses and sneak in under the cover of darkness before slicing and dicing from behind with your machete? Be the game's guest.Ubisoft Montreal isn't, of course, the first developer to do open world shooting.But it is so well executed, so technically proficient that I can't help but feel it at least matches and in some areas even surpasses other games of the genre.After choosing from a selection of nine refreshingly un-clichéd mercenaries, ranging from a 45-year-old Mauritian to a 38-year-old Algerian you're thrust into an unnamed African country being torn apart by two warring factions.Your mission: To kill The Jackal, an arms dealer who's fuelling both sides of the conflict with weapons, and making a mint as a result. You immediately run into problems - malaria wraps its diseased mitts around your innards, forcing you to collapse as soon as you arrive in town. You wake, groggily, and find The Jackal standing ominously above you. He knows everything - who you are, why you're here and how defenceless you've become as a result of the malaria. In pity, he hands you a machete and a hand gun, and lets you live. This is where Far Cry 2 kicks off.Outside, all hell breaks loose. The United Front for Liberation and Labour (UFLL) and the Alliance for Popular Resistance (APR) are going at it in the streets. You make a break for it, dodging bullets as you head anywhere as long as it's away from certain death. But there is no escape - either you're shot or you collapse from the malaria. You wake in a slaughter house just outside town. A merc, one that you did not pick to play as at the beginning of the game but is determined by that choice, now reckons you owe him a few favours on account of him saving your ♥♥♥. From there, it's up to you what jobs you take on, whether it be paid work from the UFLL or APR, malaria pill jobs from various good Samaritans, weapon vendor jobs that unlock new purchasable gear, buddy jobs that improve your 'history' with the NPC mercs or assassination jobs dished out by a disguised voice heard from communication masts. What they all have in common, however, is combat, and it's here that Far Cry 2 initially frustrates.I'm used to developers holding my hands so tightly during game tutorials, and even beyond, that Far Cry 2 will at first jar with many due to the fact that it's actually pretty tough right from the start. Simply shooting stuff is difficult. Unlike the console versions, the PC version doesn't have a snap to target function when you zoom down the barrel of your gun. This is fine - the PC keyboard and mouse set up allows for a degree of FPS accuracy console controllers simply can't. But this doesn't stop your weapons, especially at the beginning of the game, from being, frankly, crap.You'll find the recoil offensive, the jamming so regular you'll tear your hair out and the enemies so hard to spot in your splendid surroundings that it won't be long before you grab a mouthful of dirt. The healing system doesn't help. Whenever your health dips you can inject yourself with magic hit point juice. That's fine, but when your health bar is almost depleted healing will instead trigger an animation where you gruesomely pick bullets out of the holes in your skin. The problem is that this animation, which takes about five seconds to complete, is interruptible by enemy fire. Some will applaud Ubisoft Montreal's approach. Some will criticise it. Whatever your opinion, persevere. Soldier through the difficult opening few hours, keep earning diamonds, keep reducing the recoil and reliability of your weapons with upgrades, and above all, keep experimenting, because it's only through experimentation that you'll realise Far Cry 2's undoubted potential.The save system differs from the console versions in that you can save absolutely anywhere and whenever you want. There are no checkpoints in Far Cry 2, at least not in the traditional sense of the term. Instead, you'll get a pop-up asking you if you want to save after you complete mission objectives, when you use the coach transportation system or when you go to sleep using one of the Safe Houses. The many guarded checkpoints will annoy some, but for others they will reinforce the feeling that you're never safe. Because the map is so big, you'll spend a lot of your time driving around. If you're going to stick to the road, you're going to run into at least three checkpoints along the way. Every soldier manning the checkpoints has a shoot first, ask questions later policy, too, making driving more a case of survival than sight seeing. The enemies respawn, too, so you can never once and for all clear enemies from that check point on that road you keep using to get to and from town.Obviously if you're a shooter fan you should buy this game. A simple glance at the score should confirm in your mind, if there was ever any doubt, that Far Cry 2 is nothing but brilliant.

TL;DR ... for all its faults, FC2 is a 'summer popcorn movie' video game that's enjoyable if you just switch your brain off and go with the flow.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  Background  FC2 came out when 'open world' and '50+ hours of gameplay' started becoming buzzwords on games. It comes from the generation of games that were more focused on creating massive playing areas, then didn't have enough time to pad them with actual game play.  So, they slapped in a bunch of repetetive, cookie-cutter missions, scavenger hunts and enemy AI that's stupid but makes up for it by being programmed to cheat.  I got this game when it first came out, b/c I had just built a new dual-core rig (when dual-cores had just come out), and wanted to see what it could do by playing Crysis, Far Cry 2, and other games of the time. Picked it up again during steam summer sale, and the good and bad come rushing back.  To pro/con it, I have to break it down by components, since each component has pro/con.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  PLOT  Pro: it tries to delve into some deeper aspects about morality  Con: It gets pretty pretentious and self-righteous for it's own good. It's hard to follow as you're thrown right into the middle of confusion without much explanation, and even your journal and cut-scene tip text doesn't help much. But, overall, you're not missing much. You're basically a lackey for everyone, so switch your brain off and ignore thinking.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  NPC's  Pro: there's large varieties of them  Con: They were trying to cut-down on file size, so it seems they sped up everyone's dialogue after recording it. Everyone talks super-fast, which makes it difficult to follow, especially ones that have accents.   ~~~~~~~~~~~  ALLIES  Pro: you get a 'buddy' that can help revive you out in the field  Con: it feels like what they wanted to do was let you have an AI NPC follow you on missions like a side-kick. Instead, they were rushed for time, couldn't implement that, so instead they just implement some half-a**ed cutscene with a buddy helping you out, then acting completely stupid in fire fights as they die from either standing out in the middle of now where, getting caught in a brush fire like an idiot, etc, etc. Basically, to enjoy the game, just think of your Allies as nothign more then quest givers, and ignore any aspect of them 'participating' with you...because you will feel it is very lackluster if you do think of them as a 'companion'.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  MISSIONS  Pro: there's lots of them  Con: they're all the same cookie-cutter design ... go here, kill everything, collect this. I don't mind that so much (again, we're switching our brains off to enjoy this). What bothers me is you can only have 1 quest at a time. And the quest giver and the actual quest are usually on opposite sides of the massive map. So, you get a quest, spend half an hour getting there, complete it in 5 minutes, then spend another half hour getting back to the quest giver. While out and about, you will see other quest opportunities. You can't take them, or they will cancel your current quest. This is beyond dumb. For a map of this size, they should let you gather quests, then take care of all of them at once when in the area of operation.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  ENEMIES  Pro: there's a variety of enemy dress and faces, plus they use guns you can use  Con: the enemy AI is a bipolar mess of smart and dumb. You sniper a guy, and some will take cover while others try to investigate. Some will flank you and surprise you, but you realize they can only do this because their footsteps have been purposefully made extra quiet so you don't hear them. So, it feels cheap when they ambush you. The ones taking cover behind buildings won't come out. You can sneak around and pick them off with a sniper from a distance and they stay in duck-n-cover formation. I literally looked over a cliff. Saw two guys hiding. I shot one. The other guy didn't do anything. He just saw his buddy die, but he keeps hiding there. I shoot him, too. *facepalm* The devs purposefully made the AI cheat to give them a competitive advantage to challenge you. They will use their amazing eagle eyes to spot you through foliage and cover then chase or snipe you even though they are nothing but a dot in your sniper scope. Their clothes blend into the color pallette of the game, so it's hard to detect them. They will make next to no noise while walking through brush looking for you even though you sound like a herd of elephants while crouch-sneaking. When the game first came out (before patches) they were even able to run 50mph to catch up to you if you were driving through a checkpoiint without engaging them (thankfully that seems to have been fixed). But, basically... don't expect super impressive AI.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  GUNPLAY  Pro: FC2 let's you load out with a primary, secondary and support weapon. This is pretty ingenious, because it lets you tailor your load out to your play style and/or mission.  Con: I usually consider myself good at FPS (grew up on Doom and Quake), but FC2 has been brutal in run-n-gun play style. The PC is slow, can't sprint very far or fast, and likes to stop moving to do lots of activities (eg: malaria kicks in... better stop in the middle of this street while getting shot to take a pill instead of letting the player make me keep walking while doing so). Machine guns are jump as all get out, but sniper rifles have completely perfect, stationary zoom making head shots from a mile easy. Standing 10' away from a guy, you will watch as you can't hit him point-blank... unless you bring up your iron sights to target. You get a silenced sniper rifle (dart rifle), but it's not considered a primary weapon and is severely hobbled on ammo. There's just all these baffling design decisions.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  WORLD  Pro: it's large  Con: everything is the same color pallete of 'browns and greens that easily blend into each other'. The world is so large that it takes half an hour to get to your mission site. There are so many mountains that all driving feels like 'corridor' driving in that you rarely have very open areas to zoom through. Plus, when there are, there are so many trees and rocks in the way you can't really go too fast. There doesn't seem to be any permanancy in the world, too. You take a car from a place. Come back later... the car is there again, reset, as if it was never taken. And nobody gets upset over you taking vehicles. There are 'checkpoints' throughout the place where enemies hang out and make it hard to pass through. You clear one out. Come back 5 minutes later...it's repopulated again like nothing happened! This makes you feel as if your actions are pointless / worthless, and dissuades you from clearing places out. (ie: you would have incentive to clear a place out if it stayed cleared out, but since it respawns 5 seconds later, you start to just avoid conflicts by going out of your way to go around those places since they just become time wasters). Diamonds are used as currency to buy new weapons, and they spread HUNDREDS of these suit cases to go scavenger hunt all over the place to pad the game with 'game play' that isn't really compelling game play.  ~~~~~~~~~~~  Did I mention you need to switch your brain off?  There's a lot 'wrong' with the game, but it is what it is due to the open-world fantacism + huge push for better graphics that was all the rage back then (and still sort of is).  Overall, I still recommend the game, because it's entertaining going on missions and clearing places out. Sitting on a rock sniping people, pulling out a grenade launcher and blowing up vehicles with occupants still in them, tossing a moltov and lighting up a bunch of grass to burn people to death... it's mind-numbing fun.  The game is best if you fire it up, spend an hour running a mission, then turning it off for a bit.

This rivals STALKER as my favorite game of all time. As far as immersion goes, FC2 is unsurpassed. The game feels exactly like my real life experience in overthrowing an unstable African nation. Nothing in the game breaks the immersion or flow, the map is an item you can pull out and look at while driving, and the entirety of the game reinforces the brutality of the setting and the fact that you're not a golden hero, magically fixing everything for the natives. Even the ending goes for the same, I won't spoil it but suffice to say, The Jackal (FC2's antagonist) is probably my favorite character in video game history.

Good Game! I really enjoyed the open world, and it has some great rewards for exploring. Combat is excellent, giving the player a wide range of choices in how to approach a fight.   With that said, I do have a few critiques of the game that I'd like to share: 1. Reputation: This feature did not seem to help the player in any way. I thought, when I saw my reputation going up, it might have an effect like giving me some leverage with the various militant groups. Perhaps if my reputation is high enough, I would not need o fight my way through every checkpoint on the road, but no.   2. Checkpoints: Throughout the maps, different militant groups have set up checkpoints which the player must either avoid or take on in combat in order to get where they are going. I didn't mind it at first, but it became kind of tedious. It would have made sense in the game to allow the player to pass at least some of these checkpoints unscathed, considering that you are working with those same groups on your quests.  3. Limited ammo: Some of the more powerful guns understandable had limits on how much ammo could be carried. However, it seemed a bit too severe. Six darts? Really?  4. Strange weapons system: Having a warehouse with unlimited weapons and ammo was an interesting approach. However, it basically made the whole weapon condition feature pointless. If you are going to add weapon condition, and have weapons break down on the player, then it would make more sense to have the player repair those weapons, rather than giving him access to unlimited quantities of weapons in perfect condition. It's like they had an idea, then they just gave up on it.   To go a step further, let me explain. I like the weapons in the game. I like the weapons in a lot of games in fact, and I grow kind of attached to them. If I find a cool gun, I want to keep it and take care of it, and make it my gun, right? At first I liked the fact that a gun might stop working, and I might need to pick up another one, but once I found my warehouse full of unlimited guns ... it all seemed pointless.   5. No Mutant Monkeys: C'mon. Where the heck are the mutant monkeys? For nearly all of this game I was anticipating the encounter with mutant monkeys. When I discovered the second map area, I became convinced that I would discover the lair of the mutant monkeys. However, the mutant monkeys never came.   Seriously, the more I think about it, the more I resent the failure of the developer to add a simple underground lab filled with mutant monkeys. I mean, how hard can it be? And who wouldn't want mutant monkeys in their game, am I right? It's a win, win.

I've gone back-and-forth about whether to give this game a thumbs-up or thumbs-down. Ultimately, I decided to give it a thumbs-up because I *did* enjoy playing it. However, in my opinion this is a game with some serious flaws. I picked this up as part of the Far Cry franchise pack, so I don't regret buying it.  POSITIVES:  - It's a hardcore open-world sandbox FPS. If you're into that, you will almost certainly enjoy much of the game. 'Hardcore' here refers to variety of things. For example, there is very limited fast-travel. Expect to spend a lot of your time driving back and forth between the same places. This game doesn't hold your hand or give a ♥♥♥♥ about you and your time.  - Continuing the hardcore theme, you don't carry much ammo and your guns often jam, especially when you don't routinely replace them with brand new ones. I enjoyed this part, but some might see it as a nuisance.  - There is a very good variety of guns.  - The graphics hold up quite well.  NEGATIVES:  - RESPAWNING ENEMIES. This is by far the worst, IMHO. When you clear an area of enemies, they will respawn as soon as the area is unloaded. This creates some really awkward situations where your missions expect you to drive back-and-forth over the same area repeatedly, and you have to re-clear it (or painstakingly avoid it) each time. It's entertaining for the first few times, but it gets really repetitive. Early on, I died to these guys a lot. Later, I was just trying to avoid boredom by finding creative ways to kill them. I don't *mind* enemies respawning, but these ones are way too fast.  - The AI is inconsistent. Sometimes they spot you when you're hiding in the brush. Other times , they miss you when you are in the open right in front of them. I can partially forgive this, since it is an older game.  - Gun damage is very inconsistent. Five pistol shots to a bare chest at point-blank won't kill. But a sniper rifle is always a one-shot kill. I would be more forgiving of this from a normal FPS, but FC2 is obviously a game that takes itself seriously and I feel like this detracts from the 'hardcore' feeling for me.  - The two sides in the civil war are completely interchangeable. This is at least partially intentional, since the game is creating a bleak, mercenary-driven civil war where everyone is bad. However, the player hardly ever sees the two factions fighting, and both sides seem to always want to kill the main character on sight. While it's partly justifiable, it also seems a bit lazy to me. I feel like the game loses it's appeal a lot faster because of this.  - The main plot feels somewhat railroaded. For example, you *must* work for both sides of the ongoing civil war to advance the plot (i.e. one side just stops giving you missions and you need to start going to the other side). The ending was completely railroaded, as well. Some have argued that this is because the player doesn't have complete control over the main character. This is supported somewhat by the journal entries he writes during the game. However, it strikes me as a bit lazy.   Bottom Line: My enjoyment of this game was like a bell curve. Early on, I was very frustrated by some of the questionable mechanics. By the middle of the game, I had adapted, gotten a good loadout, and was having a pretty good time. But by the end of the game, the repetitiveness and plot-railroading got to me and I just wanted it to end. There's a really good game somewhere in there, though.  If it sounds appealing to you, get it while on sale or as part of the franchise pack.

There are really beautiful vistas in this game that makes you stop and just look around for a while, over and over.  It is very immersive. You are 'always' in the game. No menus to constantly interrupt you as in farcry 3. The map is held in your hand for example. I really enjoy this interface-idea, way better than farcry 3. You are no super hero that can take on everybody and thousands of bullets. You have to plan ahead and you have to be smart. You are vulnerable and everything can go wrong. You guns suddenly might jam, the fire you (accidentally) started might burn you alive if you are not careful. Perhaps your car suddenly needs repair?   AI is smart and will flank you, hide, and attack you even when wounded and lying down. Foliage is beautiful and will move and react to your running and shooting.   You do have some help (well, time will tell). You have friends who offer you help, and can even revive you if you get shot down. How you interact with these friends are totally up to you, and creates varied gameplay and events. You can work for arms dealers and upgrade your weapons and gears. You can find vehicles with mounted guns and a lot of firepower.  The game has few and short cutscenes that don't constantly interrupt and tell you what to do all the time. It is up to you, and if you have your wits about you, you can do it. It feels less like a game this way. Farcry 3 is a 'Disney roller coaster entertainmnet island'. Farcry 2 is serious work where you feel and smell the dirt, the burned oil and grass, the dust and the misery of the place.  There is wildlife, but no all over the place. They hide like real animals do. And you don't have to mass slaughter every animal to get a belt, in fact not at all.  Guns behave realistically; whatch that recoil, you can't snipe with a handgun from 200 metres away. And the weapons break. I know many hate all these problems with the guns. But for me it makes the game tense, and you always have to be on your toes, comming up with a quick alternative if something goes wrong. - You cannot always rely on your super weapon.  What is bad? Well, all these great things, are also the problem. As said before, the game is hard, sometimes too hard, and I found that I enjoyed shorter times with the game, rather than sitting for hours playing it. Every time I came back to the game, I marveled at the greatness of the game, and everytime I finished a session I was a little tired of it. It can be quite repetitive. Traveling around the map takes time and you constantly have to deal with angry people shooting at you, every time you pass a guardzone, even if you took the place out a moment ago - yes the guards respawn. Missions are not very varied either. If you compare to Farcry 3, there is not much to the game in terms of activities. The AI is tough, and sometimes it feels like they never give up. And they see you from far away with fantastic accuracy. It is not easy to sneak.  Conclusion: If you play this game like farcry 3, you will be disappointed. The game does not constantly feed you content, and happy colors. Far cry 3 is truly fantastic in its own way and improved many flaws that far cry 2 had, but far cry 2 feels so much more dynamic. The game creates content for you by interacting with the world, not by feeding constantly what to do, say and think. It the dynamic moments that are special, where anything can happen, and how you react to it. The world is more realistic and beautiful than farcry 3. In a way it feels more like roleplay, because the protagonist is silent, and the game really shines when you put effort into it, and you get immersed. But that is also the problem, do you have time to get that involved without being entertained all the time by the game?  I wish Farcry 3 (and 4) would be more a mix of far cry 2 and 3. Where you are more free to do what you want, and you are not constantly spoonfed every minute, and less collecting stuff and upgrading this and that. It felt like filler in farcry 3 that stopped you from getting on with the game. Far cry 3 is a better game. But Far cry 2 is unique, special and amazing, and it has created a deeper effect on me than far cry 3.

There's a lot to like about Far Cry 2, but it also has more than its fair share of problems. It really gets a worse rap than it deserves, even though many complaints about it are valid.  First off, the good. The game is absolutely beautiful. The CryEngine graphics look amazing, from the lush jungles, to the vast deserts, to the dilapidated villages and towns - everything is great. The character models, the vehicles, the water and waterfalls, the shifting weather patterns, the various guns - I can't say enough good things about them. The combat is visceral and satisfying, with realistic effects like guns jamming and breaking from too much use. The AI is generally smart - they communicate, flank, and call in backup, but it's inconsistent, too. Sometimes they stand in the open or leave cover when they shouldn't. Sometimes they have superhuman vision and hearing, other times they can walk right by you and not notice you at all. Overall, though, it's fun to get into firefights, and the game gives you enough leeway to decide if you want to fight up close or from a distance, quietly or loudly. The vehicles handle generally well, with the exception of the horrible hang-gliders, and there are a variety of fun ones to choose from. I really had a lot of fun playing the game for the first 20 hours or so - then the game's faults started to become more and more annoying.  I think the biggest problem with the game is the repetition. The game is far too repetitive to be as long as it is, or maybe it's far too long to be as repetitive as it is, but either way it doesn't play out well. The issue is that you literally do the same 4 or 5 missions over, and over, and over again through the entire game, all while having to drive insane distances to complete the missions, and while constantly having to clear checkpoints you've already fought your way through. Like I said, this wasn't a dealbreaker for me for the first 18 or 20 hours, but at that point I finally reached a major turning point in the plot, looked at my progress and saw that I had only finished about 50% of the game. The game then just pretty much shifted locations, but all the mission types stayed the same, and I decided that I was just getting bored with it. At that point I took a 2-month break from the game. That helped a bit, as I was able to come back in and finish, though still without the joy I had gotten from the first few hours when everything was new and fresh. The fact that the story is incomprehensible and the voice acting was absolutely painful didn't help, though, and made the game more of a chore than it needed to be.  All in all, it was a fun and amazing-looking game, despite its flaws. I got it cheap, and at 30 hours I sure can't say I didn't get my money's worth. I'd recommend it, just know that you'll have to be patient with it.

I've played through Far Cry 3 at least four times and recently completed a second play-through of Far Cry 4, so I thought I'd go back to Far Cry 2 since I’ve only played it once before. I've only gotten through a few missions now and I'm already sorry I gave it another shot. While the visuals are fairly impressive, there are so many aspects of this game that make it bad.  FC 3 did a great job of addressing the major issues with FC2 which, in when you compare the two games, really makes you aware of how bad FC2 is. The biggest problem is how long it takes to get anywhere. Traveling by vehicle speeds up your travel time, but the terrain is setup so you almost always have to go around any hills, even short ones. The map system is meant to mimic having a real map in your hand, but since you can only get a close-up view of the section you’re currently in, you can’t look around other areas to see if there is anything interesting you may want to explore. You also can’t add a waypoint to where you want to go, so when you’re traveling you constantly need to have the map deployed in order to keep visual track of where you’re trying to get to.  The ability to easily kill enemies isn’t consistent with logic. Headshots don’t always instantly kill an enemy, which I can understand if you’re at a distance and you potentially don’t get the shot dead on. However, standing right next to an enemy and shooting them in the head at point-blank range doesn’t always kill them instantly either. It would make sense that a shotgun blast to any part of the body should at least cause them to fall down, but I would frequently unload three shots at point-blank range before they tumble.  There are a number of other problems with the game, but just the combination of these two factors make the game difficult to enjoy.

I played Far Cry 2 after I played Far Cry 3.  It was neat seeing an unpolished version of what would lead to Far Cry 3. As a study in video game evolution, it might be worth it.  Pros -You can see the map while driving vehicles (you don’t have to toggle between the map and playing)  -Weapon degradation. I actually liked this. You had to make sure your weapons were in good condition before jumping into a fight. If you didn’t, they could jam, or even break, and you would have to scrounge new weapons. Undone a little by having infinite free mint weapons at the weapon store.  -The bolt-action sniper rifle is very satisfying.  Cons -No fast travel (not quite accurate, but close). Anywhere you want to go on the map, you have to move yourself. It makes you appreciate vehicles very much. There is a bus system, but the bus stops are few, and in remote areas. More than half the game will be spent in transit through the beautiful but repetitive African landscape.  -You cannot save outposts, so even if you destroy a checkpoint, on your return trip, it can still be dangerous. Nowhere is really ever safe.  -The challenge does not scale. Enemies do not become craftier, or carry better weapons, or a variety of weapons, or equip armour. The enemies you fight at the beginning are the same ones you fight at the end. From a narrative perspective, this makes sense, but as soon as you have your preferred weapon set, the game becomes a matter of rinse and repeat (again, most of which is spent driving).  -Story. The story barely exists, and does not really grab you. The main and side missions rarely seem to make sense, but you do them to progress the plot or unlock things. There is no variety (even in the dialogue) to the side missions for the gun shop or assassinations. You end up working for both sides in the conflict, but secretly, so out in the field, everyone is hostile. When you see someone, you don’t care to identify what faction they are (it doesn’t matter), or even if they’re hostile (everyone is), you just go ahead and shoot.  -Characters. The characters seem as if they were written intelligently, and then poorly executed. You never really learn what any of their motivations are, or even why they’re around. Your buddies just kind of show up, and then you’re magically friends out of nowhere. The dialogue is delivered fast, and without a pause for breath, making it sound very bizarre. Especially since the player character is silent.  -personal pet peeve: every single weapon is left-handed, but used as a right-handed weapon.  Conclusion: This game is more like a driving simulator set in a war-torn nation than an action game.

The first thing you notice about Far Cry 2 when you first set foot in (rather, sit down in) it is the absolutely gorgeous visuals and unique setting. For a game that came out all the way back in 2009, the visuals are outstanding, even when compared to new AAA titles that have come out just this year, especially if you are playing those new games on a console. This isn't only due to the setting of the game either. Most of the texture work is fantastic, with weapons and vehicles that show battle damage and rust (weapon rust is also part of a gameplay element in which your guns can jam), and excellent character models/textures. Every aesthetic element in this game screams polish. These visuals are made even more impressive when you realize the entire map is seamless. There are no loading times unless you fast travel or die, and the two parts of the map available (one unlocked later on in the game) are both absolutely massive. All of this is enhanced once you install one of the variety of different ENB mods available. Personally, I used the GES (Graphical Enhancement Suite) mod, although there are plenty more options to choose from. The only real complaint with the visuals I can think of is that the water looks good until you actually take a dive under it, at which point looks like the developers just went 'Screw it, throw a greenish-blue tint over the screen and then let's go get lunch.' This, however, is more of a nitpick than anything.  After choosing your character (none of which are female, which is a strange design decision), viewing the opening sequence and a few tutorial missions you are let loose to explore, ♥♥♥♥, pillage, and murder as you see fit. Believe me when I say you will want to explore this gorgeous setting. I am unaware of any other game that puts you in a war torn Africa, let alone one that lets you explore war torn Africa. I was compelled to explore the landscape based on the locale alone, despite the problems present should you choose to roam around. It is explained to you within your first few minutes in Africa that the only currency accepted in this land is diamonds. Doing both main and side missions rewards the player with diamonds, however they can also be found in small cases while traveling the land, with the help of a detector you get which points you in the general direction of them. This presents the first problem with just going off and exploring. There are a ton of diamond cases scattered around the map. (over 600 if memory serves) On one hand it is nice because you often run into them while doing missions anyway, however it becomes problematic if you just wish to explore to find them. The vast number of them means that each one has very few diamonds in them, anywhere from 1-5 diamonds per case. This means that trying to earn money by treasure hunting is extremely time consuming, especially when you consider that figuring out how to get to some of these cases can take upwards of 20 minutes. The second problem with exploration is that in the vanilla game (which I do not recommend playing, but we will get to that later) the checkpoints that are set up by the various mercenaries around the landscape respawn incredibly quickly. The way this works is that the map is divided into zones when viewed by the player. You can either view the entirety of the map, or view the zone you are currently in. (one zone normally constitutes an enemy checkpoint or facility) The problem occurs when you exit a zone, at which point everyone and everything that you just destroyed in the zone respawns. This can make back and forth commutes frustrating when you have to clear an area you were just in 5 seconds earlier again.  So with all that, how is the actual gameplay? The answer: pretty damn good. It is here that I will mention that I did not play the vanilla game. I played using the 'RealMode' mod on the 'Infamous' difficulty (which is the highest one), although there is another popular one called 'Dylan's Realism Mod.' The reason I did not and do not recommend playing the vanilla game is that a single enemy in the original game absorbs more bullets than ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Luffy in the entirety of One Piece. Other than making you and your enemies die like human beings should, the RealMode mod applies some balance changes to the various equipment upgrades as well. The gameplay aspect is what turns alot of people away from this game I believe. (it is a game after all) While the gunplay is solid and fun, it is the way in which the player interacts with the world that bring people to love/hate relationships with this game. The gameplay is heavily reliant on the chaos factor. What this means is that it loves putting the play in stressful situations that they have little control over. (although if you are good enough you can most definitely manipulate the environment to your favor) It is these 'Oh ♥♥♥♥ oh ♥♥♥♥ oh ♥♥♥♥' moments that truly make the game shine in my opinion. You just charged a base in your vehicle, you get out in the middle of a grassy field. The enemy comes after you. You throw a molotov cocktail, hoping to catch fire to the grass, preventing your foes from easily accessing you. But oh ♥♥♥♥, a guy you didn't see before has a rocket launcher, he fires, blows up your vehicle, now there is fire spreading to you from behind and in front, you see enemies attempting to flank you, you fire, but now your gun is jammed and the enemy closes in as you scream in your head 'WHAT DO I DO NOW OMGWTFBBQ!!!!' These kinds of unscripted, player and AI driven epic moments were easily the best part of my experience with the game. The AI is also top notch, as they will flank, call out to each other, carry wounded, and spot you from far away if you aren't careful. There is also an upgrade system for both weapons and vehicles, which you purchase from a shopkeep whom also provides you with side missions that earn you new gear. It is unfortunate however that there are only two type of sidequests in the game. There are assassination missions (which are fun and allow you creative ways to down your target) or the shopkeep missions which only ever involve taking out a convoy of vehicles. These are still enjoyable mind you, the lack of variety is just a little bit disappointing. There are alot of different loadout combinations to play and have fun with, along with a true 'do things your own way' feel. I should also mention that stealth in this game is difficult. Not impossible, just difficult due to the intelligent AI and the lack of a melee stealth takedown. Seriously developers, stealth without stealth takedowns (or at least a silent one shot melee weapon)= don't do.  Now the story, in my opinion, was not that compelling. Save for a few great moments, I honestly don't remember much about the story. It isn't bad per se, it is just sort of generic. What is good about it is the fact that later on in the game you get choices that affect the story. These choices are really just the ability to let certain people live or die. The other great part about the story is the buddy system. Some of the characters you get the option to play as before you start the game as well as some ones that you can't play as may show up in your game and offer their help. They help you in one of two ways. The first is that they will call you up during main missions and offer you an alternate way to complete the mission along with their help. This can lead to some really great moments. The second is that if you fall in battle, they will bring you back up to your feet. This is a game I love and will recommend to anyone, especially at the average sale price of $2.49. (Review shortened due to Steam character constraints)

Note: I've got more hours on the 360 version.   This is a very good sandbox FPS. Addition as of 12/5/2015:  I came across a review of this game on RPS by Alice O'Connor on August 10th, 2015. To quote:  'Far Cry 2 is a game about plans and contingency plans, then desperate makeshift plans when those both go wrong, then finally, after a crucial grenade rolls back down a hill towards you, hoping that your buddy will come pull you out the fire – and that you can cover them. [...] The problems some complain about – malaria, jamming weapons, NPC outposts respawning with silly frequency, and so on – are what make Far Cry 2 so much fun, creating more opportunities for unexpected cockups for you to triumphantly recover from. That’s where Far Cry 2 shines.'  That's exactly right. All of those things which I have seen people complain about with this game are actually part of what makes Far Cry 2 so good. The game is simply not out to make you feel like you are in control — it does EVERYTHING in its power to boost the sensation of hostility in the game world. You cleared out an enemy camp? It makes no difference, the camp will be restored by the time you come back to it. The frequent enemy respawns ensure that you never take the same route going back; it is a game about constantly improvising and measuring the stakes.  This is barely a game. It is more like an eternal struggle, a perfect fantasy for a Nietzschean male mind. That's what they wanted it to be.

There are some amazing things about Far Cry 2, but anyone who doesn't admit it's a flawed game isn't confronting reality.. You will probably either feel unable to play it or addicted to it like I was.  ON THE GOOD SIDE...  The number one thing this game does right is atmosphere. The environment is beautiful but also suspenseful and slightly terrifying. The music and sound help to achieve this atmosphere. The graphics are great. I didn't play until 2015 but they look awesome to me. The game starts out feeling almost impossible, or at least very challenging, but as you get used to the non-stop survival you start to feel like you are a force to be reckoned with. Although the fights are quite formulaic, you are totally on your own and so you feel a sense of achievement when you lay waste to hordes of enemies. The game is like a sandbox shooter: At first you feel like a child abandoned in a war zone with a pistol, but over time you realize that you can choose how to fight (balls out or stealthy) and do things your way.  I also appreciate that I didn't have any technical problems or major bugs as I played; it was quite a smooth experience.  ON THE BAD SIDE...  I have to admit I enjoyed the game quite a lot in the end (I certainly got addicted until I finished it) but there are some problems with the game. No matter how much you get used to the non-stop 'survival mode' feel - and some people absolutely love it - it always seems silly that the whole game is basically you vs a never ending rain of thugs. Everywhere you go you have to wipe down an outpost full of enemies to get anywhere, even if you just cleared it a few minutes ago. It's supposed to feel harshly realistic, but it almost feels cartoonish how much crap is thrown at you all the time. And then you get the opposite problem: You realize everything is just a formula and as soon as you get used to it, everything is too simple (almost too easy). I did say that it feels good to be the unstoppable predator and that you earned that position yourself, but it makes the game quite one-dimensional.  To sum up the gameplay problem, the game crosses the line between being difficult and being tedious. Yes you can still enjoy it, but always asking yourself why you are playing this game that is basically a map full of enemy camps you have to ravage time and time again. Also, guns you pick up from enemies jam quite often, and even your own guns can jam over and over again during certain fights. Personally I didn't see that as any kind of addition to the challenge, it was just irritating.  The only time you don't feel alone is with your buddies, which brings us to another problem. The buddy system, wherein you meet people who provide missions or can save your hide when you get knocked out, feels incomplete. After playing the game to the end, I still have no idea what 'reputation' or doing extra side missions did for me. I'm pretty sure the answer is nothing.. The main interaction you have with buddies is that your best friend at any given time will call you after you receive each story mission and offer you a bizarre, convoluted way to do the mission. Sometimes it makes the mission more interesting, but given the brutal nature of the game I would usually just groan that I was given an extra set of tasks.  A quick note about the ending, which is SORT OF A SPOILER but not really. Actually, I might be doing you a favor if you play the game. Once you beat the final mission, you cannot go back and wrap up side stuff that you didn't finish. Considering there are 221 diamonds to find in the game (ugh) it's a bit funny. I guess this is just a choice developers make when ending the story of a sandbox game, but I personally never like when this happens. I wanted to wrap up the last side missions and diamond hunting, but now that I finished the story I don't feel compelled to load an old save and do all that again.  Also, the credits are like 10 minutes long and you can't skip them... I don't understand.  ALTOGETHER  This game is worth playing for the good parts, but for some the flaws can't be forgiven and I can honestly totally understand that. I actually almost put the game down the first time I realized that everywhere you go you will be attacked PLUS patrol cars make the roads unsafe as well.  A word of advice if you plan to play this game: Take it SLOW. Although it's kind a repetitive game, you'll still find it more enjoyable if you take it in and play wisely. If you try to rush all the time, you will probably just get frustrated (although I did choose to fly in with a truck and blow everything up half the time, instead of going stealthy). Also, buying the camo suit upgrade is a must, and I personally could not play without the silenced weapons.
Now that's what I call a huge improvement on a sequel!

I wanted to make a list of all the improvements FC3 brought to the series, but had to stop because the improvements are way too many for a short review.   I will allow myself to elaborate on some of the things that bothered me with a concrete example of FC:2:s gameplay: Say I want to travel to a safehouse and enjoy the facilities of it.   There is no fast way to travel to safehouses, in fact, contrary to what it's name suggests, the road to your safehouse is often very perilous, which defeats the purpose of getting there in the first place.  Now, there is a way to fast-travel in this game: it takes the form of a bus. The bus can take you to a different region on the map, but almost none of the bus stations are located close to a safehouse, to which you can travel, without hitting an OUTPOST. The outposts are always populated by enemies that shoot you on sight. You can either slowly sneak past the outpost, try to dash through it with a vehicle and hope they won't pursue you in one of their own, or you can, of course, wipe them out. Shooting things is fun, but one would think that killing everyone in an outpost might secure passage through later on. This is not the case though since enemies respawn every time you revisit the outpost.  You make it past anyway and carry on all the way to the safehouse. Here you can sleep and save the game! Yay! Saving the game in a safehouse is completely meaningless, since you can save the game anytime anywhere conditionless of your situation. Sleeping makes time pass by, so you can choose to play at morning, day, evening and night. This seems to be little more than esthetic. I can also choose to store a weapon here. I can take one of the weapons I have on my person and store it in one of the weapon boxes, provided I've bought one of those boxes. Now I have an empty weapon slot, but, should I int he future have wrong weapon for the occasion, I might travel here and pick up whatever weapon I stored here instead! Since I visit the weapon store frequently, buying improved weapons constantly AND since all my previous purchased weapons spawn here infinitly, this safehouse-weapon-storage feels like a self-defeating purpose. Wouldn't it be better to just have a caché or a safe in your safehouse with all the weapons you have acquired so far?   It might be fair to say that this game doesn't go easy on you and it doesn't give you anything (ANYTHING) without effort from the gamer. Maybe it's not particularily bad, just detrimentally cruel.
